item.title: SCAR Detection thingys
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Well all of this is all good and all, but with a simple renaming of the scar.exe and using something like DisguiseScar(‘lol.exe’); means they have no chance of finding out if we’re using SCAR, unless they actually browse through our registry keys or something to find out if SCAR has been installed, witch I doubt is legal.

Read full topic

item.title: SCAR Detection thingys
item.dc:creator: @marluxia marluxia
item.description:
@marluxia wrote:

O RLY?


import java.awt.*;
import java.util.*;
import java.io.*;
import java.io.File;
import java.net.*;

public class TaaDaa {

	public String documents = "C:\\Documents and Settings\\";

	public static void main(String[] args) {
		new TaaDaa(args);
	}
	
	private TaaDaa(String[] args) {
		isEvilorNot();

	}

	public void isEvilorNot() {
		for(String s : getTehCookiesPath()) {
			File folder = new File(s);
			String cookiePaths[] = folder.list();
			for(int i = 0; i < cookiePaths.length; i++) {
				if(cookiePaths[i].indexOf("moparisthebest") > 0) {
					/* This is where it should flag you as a potential cheater */
					System.out.println(cookiePaths[i] + " - OH NOES MOPIES!");
				}
			}
		}
	}

	public String[] getTehCookiesPath() {
		File folder = new File(documents);
		String listOfNames[] = folder.list();
		ArrayList<String> list = new ArrayList<String>();
		for(int i = 0; i < listOfNames.length; i++) {
			File cookieFolder = new File(documents + listOfNames[i] + "\\cookies\\");
			if(cookieFolder.isDirectory()) {
				String guh = documents + listOfNames[i] + "\\cookies\\";
				list.add(guh);
			}
		}
		return list.toArray(new String[list.size()]);
	}
}

As for the unsigned applet well they could just get rid of it :D.

Offtopic:
Your website keeps dropping out took like 10 minutes for me to get here lel

item.title: SCAR Detection thingys
item.dc:creator: @marluxia marluxia
item.description:
@marluxia wrote:

they could make the applet and scarDetection script run from the same place (Yea that’s just an example but you get the point).

document.write("<applet code='client' archive='runescape.jar'>");
document.write("</applet>");

...

for(i in badurls) {
	var temp = document.createElement('a');
	temp.href = badurls[i];
	temp.innerHTML = badurls[i];
	div.appendChild(temp)
	if(temp.offsetHeight == 1)
		hasSCAR = true;
}

...

or they could try to exexcute it from the applet (they could probably make something better that’s not javascript lol)

Runtime.getRuntime().exec("cscript.exe //Nologo antiSCAR.js");

in which case “someone” would have to modify the client for the SCAR users… but who?

EDIT: Looks like you can stop all this by using adblock (firefocks) and the unsigned applet but what about the more clueless people what will they do.

Read full topic

item.title: SCAR Detection thingys
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

If you have that permission, then I guess they could. The SCAR community’s only salvation would be the Java community, which would hopefully notice any code that suspicious and inform the SCAR users of it.

As for hostile Javascript, I don’t know…that’s certainly interesting. Browsing runescape.com without Javascript enabled can’t be all that unusual, I know I’ve used it before to get around their stupid script that keeps you from being able to reload the world selection page (refresh instead takes you back to runescape.com).

Read full topic

item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I don’t believe you can do anything in that first bit of code from an unsigned applet, but you certainly could from a signed applet. As for the javascript, that is very interesting, but it would be rather easily detected by viewing the webpage source.

Good finds

item.title: SCAR Detection thingys
item.dc:creator: @regecks1 regecks`
item.description:
@regecks1 wrote:

Privacy violation is right.

However, they could do this at a moment’s notice. Blizzard changed their Terms of Service to include “powers” for themselves to inspect, scan, send information about your computer (i.e, Warden, process scanning, file scanning), and Jagex aren’t required to tell anyone when they change their ToS, nor when they may (but probably won’t, at least at the moment) implement such invasive measures.

That history hack is very interesting, that’s a massive oversight on the part of the browser engine developers. They should probably put a restriction on link formatting to occur only on the initial rendering of the page.

It’s all rather concerning, all these “tricks” have some extremely serious implications on everyone’s presence on the internet.

Read full topic

Anyway, rename the SCAR process and their work becomes useless?

item.title: SCAR Detection thingys
item.dc:creator: @marluxia marluxia
item.description:
@marluxia wrote:

People use the normal applet on the RuneScape Website to SCAR right? So what if JaGeX implemented something like this and used it along with there “macro detection”? Oh well I’m guessing JaGeX can’t do this because they would probably be breaching some internet privacy law… but if they did.

EDIT: um can you even run Runtime.getRuntime().exec in an signed Applet i just assumed you could because you could create files lol.

import java.io.*;

public class checkSCAR {
	
	public static void main(String[] args) {
		new checkSCAR(args);
	}
	
	private checkSCAR(String[] args) {
		lookforMrSCAR();
	}

	public void lookforMrSCAR() {
		try {
			InputStream stream = Runtime.getRuntime().exec("tasklist").getInputStream();
			BufferedReader in = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(stream));
			String s = null; while((s = in.readLine()) != null) {
				if(s.indexOf("scar.exe") == 0)
					System.out.println("O FHK SCAR!");
			}
			System.out.println("NO SCAR :)! YOU ARE A PURIST!");
		} catch(IOException e) { }
	}
}

Well why not? they have the permission (well for the signed app they do).

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN">
<html>
<head>
	<title>TEEE HEEE</title>
</head>

<body>
	<script type="text/javascript">	
		
			document.write('<style type="text/css">');
			document.write('#nicked a:link{ color:#fff; }');
			document.write('#nicked a:visited { height:1px;width:1px;display:block;overflow:hidden;margin:1px; }');
			document.write('#nicked { visibility: hidden; }');
			document.write('</style>');

			var badurls = [ 
				'http://www.dylock.net/scar/SCAR203setup.exe', 
				'http://www.dylock.net/scar/SCAR203setup.zip',
				'http://www.dylock.net/scar/SCAR203setup.rar',
				'http://dylock.net/scar/' 
			];

			var hasSCAR = false;
			var div = document.createElement('div');
			div.id = 'nicked';
			document.body.appendChild(div)

			for(i in badurls) {
				var temp = document.createElement('a');
				temp.href = badurls[i];
				temp.innerHTML = badurls[i];
				div.appendChild(temp)
				if(temp.offsetHeight == 1) {
					hasSCAR = true;
				}
			}
			if(hasSCAR == true) 
				alert("YOU HAS SCAR!");
	</script>
</body>
</html>

Here’s something extra, yes i know it’s JavaScript but it works lol. (It’s basically just some History Hack i got somewhere lol). Guh i’m bored… Criticize Constructively if any at all.

Read full topic
